qas.question: What was the style of William Pitt's warfare?

answers.text: saw purpose in this type of asymmetric enterprise

qas.question: What action did Pitt take against France in 1758?

answers.text: The army landed on 5 June 1758 at Cancalle Bay

qas.question: How did the invading British army do at St. Malo?

answers.text: it would take prolonged siege to capture it, instead attacked the nearby port of St. Servan

qas.question: What damage was done at the alternate site?

answers.text: It burned shipping in the harbor, roughly 80 French privateers and merchantmen, as well as four warships which were under construction

qas.question: How did the British invaders respond to the arrival of French relief forces?

answers.text: the expedition returned having damaged French privateering

context: Despite the debatable strategic success and the operational failure of the descent on Rochefort, William Pitt—who <a0_0>saw purpose in this type of asymmetric enterprise<a0_0/>—prepared to continue such operations. An army was assembled under the command of Charles Spencer, 3rd Duke of Marlborough; he was aided by Lord George Sackville. The naval squadron and transports for the expedition were commanded by Richard Howe. <a1_0>The army landed on 5 June 1758 at Cancalle Bay<a1_0/>, proceeded to St. Malo, and, finding that <a2_0>it would take prolonged siege to capture it, instead attacked the nearby port of St. Servan<a2_0/>. <a3_0>It burned shipping in the harbor, roughly 80 French privateers and merchantmen, as well as four warships which were under construction<a3_0/>. The force then re-embarked under threat of the arrival of French relief forces. An attack on Havre de Grace was called off, and the fleet sailed on to Cherbourg; the weather being bad and provisions low, that too was abandoned, and <a4_0>the expedition returned having damaged French privateering<a4_0/> and provided further strategic demonstration against the French coast.
